t: Job 14
Anyone*pn born of woman is*ln short of days and full of trouble.
He*ln blossoms like a flower, then withers; he*ln flees like a shadow and does not last.
Do*ln you really take notice of one like this? Will*ln you bring me into judgment against you?
Who*ln can produce something pure from what is impure? No*ln one!
Since*ln a person’s days are determined and*ln the number of his months depends on you, and*ln since you have set limits he cannot pass,
look*ln away from him and let him rest so*ln that he can enjoy his day like a hired worker.
There*pn is hope for a tree: If*ln it is cut down, it will sprout again, and*ln its shoots will not die.
If*ln its roots grow old in the ground and*ln its stump starts to die in the soil,
the*ln scent of water makes it thrive and*ln produce twigs like a sapling.
But*ln a person dies and fades away; he*ln breathes his last - where is he?
As*ln water disappears from a lake and*ln a river becomes parched and dry,
so*ln people lie down never to rise again. They*ln will not wake up until the heavens are no more; they*ln will not stir from their sleep.
If*pn only you would hide me in Sheol and*ln conceal me until your anger passes. If*ln only you would appoint a time for me and*ln then remember me.
When*ln a person dies, will he come back to life? If*ln so, I would wait all the days of my struggle until*ln my relief comes.
You*ln would call, and I would answer you. You*ln would long for the work of your hands.
For*ln then you would count my steps but*ln would not take note of my sin.
My*ln rebellion would be sealed up in a bag, and*ln you would cover over my iniquity.
But*pn as a mountain collapses and crumbles and*ln a rock is dislodged from its place,
as*ln water wears away stones and*ln torrents wash away the soil from the land, so*ln you destroy a man’s hope.
You*ln completely overpower him, and he passes on; you*ln change his appearance and send him away.
If*ln his sons receive honor, he does not know it; if*ln they become insignificant, he is unaware of it.
He*ln feels only the pain of his own body and*ln mourns only for himself.
